caption: Table 1: Evaluation results on DREAM-1K. We report F1/Precision/Recall scores for each category and for the overall dataset. For open-source models, all results are tested with their official checkpoint and inference code under recommended setting. SOTA results of comparable scale (<<<10B) are bolded and overall best results are underlined.
description: Table 1 presents a performance comparison of various models on the DREAM-1K video captioning benchmark.  It shows F1 scores, precision, and recall for each video category (Live-action, Animation, Stock, YouTube Shorts) and an overall average.  The table distinguishes between proprietary models (GPT-4V, GPT-40, Gemini models) and open-source models (those with parameter counts above and below 10B).  Open-source model results were obtained using their official checkpoints and code, under recommended settings. The best-performing models of comparable size (<10B parameters) are highlighted in bold, and the overall best-performing model is underlined. This provides a comprehensive view of Tarsier2's performance relative to other leading video captioning models.

caption: Table 2: Evaluation results on E.T. Bench-Captioning. Results marked in gray are tested on a subset. ††{\dagger}† denotes the model is fine-tuned on E.T. Instruct 164K. All results are transcribed from the official benchmark, except for LLaVA-OV, LLaVA-Video and Qwen2-VL, which are our evaluation using the official checkpoint and inference code.
description: This table presents a performance comparison of various large vision-language models (LVLMs) on the E.T. Bench-Captioning benchmark, focusing on video captioning tasks.  The benchmark contains four subtasks assessing the models' ability to generate video captions.  Results include the F1 score, precision and recall for each subtask, and average scores across subtasks.  Models are categorized into proprietary and open-source models, with a further breakdown based on their parameter size. Results for some open-source models are from the authors' own evaluations using the models' official checkpoints and code, while others are taken directly from the official benchmark.  Note that results marked in gray are from a subset of the benchmark dataset.

caption: Table 3: Evaluation results on short video question answering benchmarks. * indicates that the training set has been observed in the training data mixture.
description: This table presents a comparison of the performance of different models on several short-video question answering benchmarks.  The benchmarks assess a model's ability to understand and reason about the visual content in short videos.  The results are shown for various models, including both proprietary and open-source models, categorized by their size (less than 10 billion parameters or greater than 10 billion parameters). The '*' symbol indicates when a model's training data included instances from the test set of that particular benchmark, potentially affecting the score due to data leakage.

The number of frames sampled from each video during evaluation is also listed for Tarsier2, indicating the model's performance under varying temporal resolutions.

caption: Table 5: Evaluation results on hallucination benchmarks.
description: This table presents a quantitative evaluation of various large vision-language models (LVLMs) on two hallucination benchmarks: VideoHallucer and EventHallusion.  For each benchmark, it shows the performance of several models (both proprietary and open-source) on two sub-tasks. The first is a yes/no question answering task, while the second task assesses the quality of detailed video descriptions generated by the model.  The table allows comparison of the models' ability to generate accurate and complete video descriptions without hallucinations, a common issue in video understanding tasks.

caption: Table 6: Evaluation results on E.T. Bench-Grounding. Results marked in gray are tested on a subset. ††{\dagger}† denotes the model is fine-tuned on E.T. Instruct 164K.
description: This table presents a comprehensive comparison of various models' performance on the E.T. Bench-Grounding benchmark.  The benchmark evaluates video grounding capabilities across several subtasks.  The table shows each model's performance (F1 scores) on different aspects of video grounding, including temporal and visual grounding.  Results marked in gray indicate that the model was evaluated on a subset of the benchmark, not the entire dataset.  A † symbol signifies that the model has undergone fine-tuning using the E.T. Instruct 164K dataset, enhancing its performance.

caption: Table 7: Evaluation results on embodied question-answering tasks, including EgoTaskQA, RoboVQA and OpenEQA.
description: This table presents a comparison of the performance of various models on three embodied question-answering benchmarks: EgoTaskQA, RoboVQA, and OpenEQA.  For each benchmark, the table shows the performance metrics used to evaluate the models, along with the scores achieved by each model. The benchmarks assess a model's ability to understand and respond to questions in realistic, interactive environments, such as those encountered in robotics.  The inclusion of three benchmarks allows for a comprehensive assessment of model capabilities across diverse embodied question-answering scenarios.

caption: Table 8: Results of the ablation study for pre-training. Tarsier1-7b-Qwen stands for the model where the base model is upgraded to Qwen2-VL, while the pre-training dataset remains the same as Tarsier1. Tarsier2 is trained from Qwen2-VL with an expanded pre-training dataset, growing from 13 million in Tarsier1 to 40 million samples.
description: This table presents the ablation study results for the pre-training phase of the Tarsier2 model.  It compares three model configurations: the original Tarsier1-7B model, a version upgraded with the Qwen2-VL base model (Tarsier1-7B-Qwen), and the final Tarsier2-7B model. The key difference between Tarsier1 and Tarsier2 is the size of the pre-training dataset, which increased from 13 million to 40 million video-text pairs.  The table shows the performance of each model variant across several video understanding tasks including captioning, video question answering (both short and long), and hallucination.  This allows for a clear assessment of the individual contribution of both the base model upgrade and the increased dataset size to the overall performance improvements.

caption: Table 9: Ablation study of temporal grounding dataset during the SFT phase. Tarsier2-7B-SFT refers to the model after the SFT phase. w/o SFT refers to the model after pre-training; w/o grounding refers to the model fine-tinued without grounding information.
description: This table presents an ablation study on the impact of temporal grounding during the supervised fine-tuning (SFT) phase of the Tarsier2 model.  It compares the performance of the full Tarsier2 model (after SFT) to two ablation variants. The first ablation ('w/o SFT') represents the model's performance after only pre-training, and the second ablation ('w/o grounding') shows the results of a model fine-tuned without the temporal grounding information in the training data. The performance is measured across multiple video understanding tasks, including video captioning (DREAM-1K, TempCompass-cg, Vinoground-Text), short and long video question answering, and a hallucination test. The results illustrate the importance of temporal grounding during fine-tuning for achieving better accuracy across these video understanding tasks.

caption: Table 10: Ablation study for DPO training phase, negative sampling (NS) and preference data filtering (PF) strategies.
description: This table presents the ablation study results focusing on the impact of Direct Preference Optimization (DPO), negative sampling (NS), and preference data filtering (PF) strategies on the overall performance of the Tarsier2 model. It evaluates the model's performance across various video understanding tasks, including video captioning, video question answering, and hallucination detection, by comparing the results obtained with the complete DPO training pipeline to results obtained without DPO, without NS, and without PF, respectively. This provides insights into the effectiveness and individual contribution of each component in enhancing the model's capabilities.

caption: Table 11: The experimental results of recaptioning. “Recaption FT” represents fine-tune the model on the Tarsier2-Recap-585K dataset. “Original FT” represents fine-tune the model with the same videos as Tarsier2-Recap-585K but taking their original labels as target output.
description: This table presents the results of fine-tuning two models on the Tarsier2-Recap-585K dataset. The first model was fine-tuned using the new captions generated for the dataset, while the second model was fine-tuned using the original captions. The table compares the performance of both fine-tuned models and the original Qwen2-VL-7B model across various video understanding tasks, including video captioning, video question answering, and hallucination detection.  Performance metrics include F1 scores, accuracy, and recall, providing a comprehensive evaluation of the impact of using different captions during the fine-tuning process.

caption: Table 12: Training hyper-parameters of Tarsier2
description: This table details the hyperparameters used during the three stages of Tarsier2 training: pre-training, supervised fine-tuning (SFT), and direct preference optimization (DPO).  For each stage, it lists the optimizer used (AdamW), its hyperparameters (beta1, beta2, epsilon), the learning rate, learning rate schedule (cosine), the number of training steps, the number of warm-up steps, weight decay, gradient clipping, dropout rate, global batch size, maximum number of pixels, number of frames per video, and the numerical precision used (bfloat16).  The table provides a comprehensive overview of the training configurations employed for each stage of Tarsier2's development.

caption: Table 13: Datasets and their sizes used in Tarsier2 pre-training. ††\dagger† indicates in-house datasets.
description: Table 13 details the datasets used in the pre-training phase of the Tarsier2 model.  It breaks down the data by category (video captioning, action recognition, video QA, grounding, video self-supervised training, image understanding, and text generation), listing the specific dataset name and the number of samples used for each.  The table also differentiates between publicly available datasets and those that were created in-house for the research.  The use of in-house data is indicated by a dagger symbol next to the dataset name.  This table helps to understand the scale and diversity of data used to train the Tarsier2 model, which contributes to its performance.

caption: Table 14: Detailed results of the ablation study for pre-training. For the captioning task, results are reported after the SFT stage. For other tasks, results are reported after the pre-training stage.
description: This table presents a detailed ablation study analyzing the impact of pre-training on various video understanding tasks.  It compares the performance of three different models: the base Tarsier1-7B model, an upgraded version (Tarsier1-7B-Qwen) using a better base model, and the final Tarsier2-7B model trained with significantly more data. The results are categorized into three main task types: Captioning (DREAM-1K, TempCompass-cg, and Vinoground-Text), Video Question Answering (short and long video QA), and Hallucination.  For captioning, results reflect performance after the supervised fine-tuning (SFT) stage to ensure fair comparison.  All other tasks' results are directly from the pre-training stage.

caption: Table 15: Detailed results of the ablation study for SFT.
description: This table presents a detailed breakdown of the ablation study conducted on the supervised fine-tuning (SFT) stage of the Tarsier2 model. It compares the model's performance across various video understanding tasks under different SFT configurations. Specifically, it contrasts the full SFT model against versions without fine-tuning (w/o SFT) and versions trained without the fine-grained temporal grounding information (w/o grounding). This allows for a quantitative assessment of the impact of the SFT process and the importance of temporal grounding on the model's overall capabilities.

caption: Table 16: Detailed results of the ablation study for DPO.
description: This table presents a detailed breakdown of the ablation study conducted on the Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) training phase. It shows the performance of the Tarsier2-7B model on various video understanding tasks (captioning, video question answering, and hallucination) under different DPO training settings.  Specifically, it compares the full model against versions without DPO, without negative sampling, and without preference filtering. This allows for a precise evaluation of the contribution of each component of the DPO process to the overall performance.

caption: Table 17: Detailed results of the recaptioning experiment.
description: This table presents a detailed breakdown of the recaptioning experiment's results.  It compares the performance of the Qwen2-VL-7B model before and after fine-tuning on the Tarsier2-Recap-585K dataset, showcasing improvements across various video understanding tasks (captioning, video question answering, and hallucination).  The table details the model's performance metrics (F1 score, precision, recall, and accuracy) for each task and benchmark, highlighting the impact of the additional training data.

caption: Table 18: Data composition of Tarsier2-Recap-585K. The “Split” column lists the original dataset partitioning, and we use bold to mark the parts which we sampled the video clips from to conduct recaptioning.
description: Table 18 details the composition of the Tarsier2-Recap-585K dataset, used for video recaptioning. It lists the original datasets, their video clip count, the split of the data (train, validation, test), and the average duration of the clips.  The table also indicates which portions of each original dataset were sampled for inclusion in Tarsier2-Recap-585K, highlighting the selection process used to create the recaptioning dataset.
